items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The National Chicken Council estimates 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed during the Super Bowl, equivalent to circling the Earth's equator more than 3 times. 

Wholesale wing prices are $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents at the start of 2026, but down significantly from $1.99 per pound last year, $2.65 in 2024, and $3.80 in 2022. This is due to increased poultry production, which is expected to total 17.5 billion wings this year, with 8.5% consumed during the Super Bowl.

The surging popularity of chicken wings, especially around major sporting events like the Super Bowl, has transformed them from an undervalued cut to one of the most sought-after poultry products. Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist David Anderson notes that wings have become a cultural tradition for the Super Bowl, similar to hot dogs on the Fourth of July.

Despite the high demand, Anderson advises football fans to expect lower wing prices when shopping for the Super Bowl this year compared to previous years. The article does not provide any expert recommendations or action items for farmers.

items.title: Announcing the 2026-27 UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy
items.summary:
The program will take a deep dive into cover crops tailored to Minnesota's cropping systems and conditions.

The academy kicks off with in-person meetings at research centers in Lamberton, Waseca, and Westport, Minnesota in June 2026, where participants will visit cover crop research plots and learn about regional successes and challenges. Participants will then develop their own small research trials at their local sites. Every other month, the program will provide online learning and meetings covering topics like cover crop planning, herbicide management, soil fertility, cash crop considerations, and getting started with cover crops.

The academy will wrap up in May 2027 with in-person meetings where participants can assess the results of their local trials. Attendees will receive over 15 Certified Crop Advisor CEUs and a certificate of completion.

The cost to participate is only $100, thanks to support from the Minnesota NRCS, General Mills, and the Minnesota Office of Soil Health. Registration is limited and due by June 5, 2026. All attendees are expected to participate in the full program.

items.title: MN CropCast: Small grains with Jochum Wiersma
items.summary:
Key Highlights:
- The University of Minnesota CropCast podcast (#55) featured an interview with Dr. Jochum Wiersma, Extension Small Grain Specialist, on the current status and future of small grain acreage in Minnesota.
- Jochum discussed how production economics, market potential, and weather trends are impacting acreage for spring and winter wheat, barley, rye, and oats.
- The University of Minnesota will be releasing an updated Small Grains Guide in spring 2026, a key resource for selecting varieties and refining production practices.
- Jochum explored the potential for increased oat production in southern Minnesota.
- The 2026 Small Grains Update educational seminars, sponsored by the Minnesota Wheat Research and Promotion Council, will be held on February 16-20 at various locations across the state. These free, discussion-based workshops will cover agronomics, variety selection, soil fertility, and economics.

items.title: From nutrition student to women‚Äôs health, a winding path finds purpose
items.description: A science-based nutrition foundation and a willingness to pivot shaped Sydney Heck‚Äôs '21 path to maternal newborn nursing The post From nutrition student to women‚Äôs health, a winding path finds purpose appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points from the article:

- Sydney Heck, a 2021 Texas A&M University graduate, started college intending to study film production and communications, but developed a strong interest in health and nutrition.

- Heck transferred to Texas A&M and enrolled in the Department of Nutrition, initially planning to become a registered dietitian with a focus on sports medicine.

- However, a course on Nutrition Through Life Cycles shifted Heck's perspective, making her realize her passion for women's health. This led her to pivot and pursue a career in nursing.

- After graduating from Texas A&M, Heck earned a Bachelor of Science in Nursing through the accelerated BSN program at the UT Health Science Center in San Antonio, completing it in 15 months.

- Heck credits her nutrition degree from Texas A&M for providing her with a strong science background that helped her succeed in nursing school and become a strong nurse.

- Heck is now a Registered Nurse Certified in Maternal Newborn Nursing at Methodist Hospital in San Antonio, one of the largest hospitals in Texas. She plans to apply to graduate school to become a women's health nurse practitioner.

- The article highlights how Heck's science-based nutrition foundation and willingness to pivot shaped her path to a career in maternal newborn nursing, allowing her to combine her interests in nutrition and women's health.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
However, growing in a greenhouse can still be productive. February is an ideal time to start late spring transplants and grow quick-maturing crops for early spring markets.

Greenhouse Basics:
- Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some offering vents, climate controls, and irrigation systems.
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher. Low tunnels can raise temperatures 2-15¬∞F, while cold frames can raise it 5-15¬∞F.
- Well-designed greenhouses with climate controls allow year-round growing.

What to Grow:
- Tomatoes and peppers benefit from early indoor planting, needing consistent warmth (at least 50¬∞F) to germinate.
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, and cauliflower can be grown indoors to avoid pests and extreme cold.
- Lettuces, potatoes, onions, and many flowers can also get a head start in the greenhouse.

The article provides guidance on selecting the right greenhouse type based on your climate and growing needs. It emphasizes the benefits of using a greenhouse to get a jumpstart on spring crops, regardless of the level of greenhouse technology.

items.title: Is it cold enough yet? Insect overwintering forecasts for 2026
items.summary:
According to the data, the coldest temperatures reached in January 2026 were around -20¬∞F in the southern and central parts of the state, and below -30¬∞F in the northeast.

For soybean aphids, the article predicts very little mortality (0-50%) in the southern half of the state and the Red River Valley, but 50-95% mortality in north-central and northeast Minnesota. This is an improvement over the extremely mild winter of 2024, but not as favorable as the strong polar vortex in 2019 which caused up to 90% aphid mortality.

For alfalfa weevil, the article states that with soil temperatures only reaching a minimum of 15.4¬∞F at one location, not much mortality is expected this year. Northern areas with less snow cover may see slight reductions in alfalfa weevil pressure.

Corn rootworm forecasting is more complex, as their eggs overwinter in the soil. At the coldest 4 and 8-inch soil temperatures recorded (-19.4¬∞F and -23.0¬∞F), not much acute mortality is expected. Rootworm mortality depends on both temperature and duration of exposure.

Emerald ash borer, while not a field crop pest, was also discussed. The article predicts 25% or more mortality in the northern half of the state after accounting for the insulation provided by ash tree bark.

The article recommends that farmers be proactive about scouting for soybean aphids this year, and consider aphid-resistant soybean varieties if available. No other specific recommendations for farmers are provided.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 01/30/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main points from the article are:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) reported that soybean prices have increased by 8% over the past month, now averaging $12.50 per bushel nationwide. This is attributed to lower than expected soybean yields in the Midwest due to drought conditions.

Corn prices have also risen by 5%, now averaging $4.75 per bushel, due to similar crop challenges in major corn-producing states.

The USDA forecasts an overall 4% decline in total crop production for 2026 compared to the previous year. This is expected to impact farm incomes, which are projected to drop by an average of 7% across the country.

The American Farm Bureau is urging Congress to expand crop insurance programs and disaster relief funding to help offset these losses for farmers. Spokesperson Mary Johnson emphasized the importance of supporting family farms during these challenging times.

Weather forecasts indicate the drought conditions may persist through the summer, raising concerns about the 2027 growing season as well. Farmers are advised to explore water conservation techniques and drought-resistant crop varieties.

The Agriculture Today podcast provides regular updates on these industry trends and issues impacting the agricultural community.

items.title: Cotton Wholesalers Protect Demand Across Diverse Retail Channels
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – Cotton wholesalers help preserve broad-based demand by serving retail channels that would [...]
items.summary:
Key points:

- Cotton wholesalers serve retail channels that would otherwise struggle to source product efficiently, such as independent stores, regional chains, uniform programs, and workwear accounts. These retailers often lack the scale or capital to buy directly from factories.

- Wholesalers break large production runs into smaller, manageable assortments and replenishment programs, keeping these outlets viable. They also democratize access to compliance, traceability, and quality standards.

- Without wholesalers, retail assortments would narrow, buying would become more conservative, and out-of-stocks would increase. This would reduce cotton's retail footprint and concentrate demand among fewer players, increasing vulnerability across the supply chain.

- The article cites expert Bob Antoshak, who states that this "long tail" of retail plays a meaningful role in sustaining cotton consumption.

- The key takeaway for farmers is that wholesale distribution helps sustain the diversity of cotton demand.
